case_name: Appellant v. State of West Bengal

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 52 of 1955 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 52 of 1955. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated 15th February 1955 of Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 40 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated the 15th February, 1955, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 40 of 1955 arising out

facts.text: High Court appeal arose from judgment dated 22nd January 1955 of Additional Sessions Judge, 24 Parganas, Alipore, in Trial No. 1 of January Sessions 1955.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated the 22nd January, 1955, of the Additional Sessions Judge, 24 Parganas, Alipore, in Trial No. 1 of January Sessions for 1955.

facts.text: Appellant convicted under s. 376 IPC for committing rape on Sudharani Roy, aged about 14-15 years.

anchor.surface_text: holding the appellant guilty under s. 376 of the Indian Penal Code, for having committed rape on a young girl, named Sudharani Roy, said to be about 14-15 years of age.

facts.text: Jury returned unanimous verdict of guilty against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial judge, accepting the unanimous verdict of the jury and agreeing with it, imposed a deterrent punishment

facts.text: Trial judge imposed rigorous imprisonment for 5 years on appellant.

anchor.surface_text: imposed a deterrent punishment of rigorous imprisonment for 5 years, in view of the fact that he was in loco parentis to the large number of girls

facts.text: Appellant was secretary of Nari Kalyan Ashram for a long time.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court Division Bench summarily dismissed appeal on February 15, 1955 without reasons.

anchor.surface_text: is directed against the order of a Division Bench of that Court, dated February 15, 1955, summarily dismissing an appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court granted by High Court bench on March 18, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was heard again on March 17, and on March 18, the learned Chief Justice delivered a judgment which appears at pages 220 to 231

facts.text: Appellant was honorary secretary of Nari Kalyan Ashram in Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was the honorary secretary of a large institution for receiving and looking after young girls and women who had no homes

facts.text: Appellant visited Ashram daily at about 7 p.m. and stayed till midnight or past.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in his capacity as the secretary, used to come to the Ashram daily in the evening at about 7 p.m., and stay there till mid-night

facts.text: Rape committed on Narmaya and Sudharani on night of April 20, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On April 29, 1954, at about 10 p.m., the officer-in-charge of the Maniktala police station, accompanied by Sub-Inspector Nirmal Chandra Kar,

facts.text: Narmaya and Sudharani alleged rape to police on April 29, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Narmaya and Sudharani are said to have given information to the said officer-in-charge of the police station, alleging rape on them.

facts.text: Police found rubber sheath in steel locker in appellant's room on April 29, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The police officers aforesaid obtained the key from the appellant, with which the steel locker was opened and a leather bag inside the locker

facts.text: Charge-sheet submitted against appellant after investigation.

anchor.surface_text: After recording the information, the police officer-in-charge of the Maniktala police station, investigated the case and submitted a charge-sheet

facts.text: Appellant committed to Sessions Court for trial under s.376 IPC on two girls.

anchor.surface_text: After the preliminary inquiry by a magistrate, the appellant was committed for trial to the Court of Session on a charge of rape upon the two girls,

facts.text: Appellant's defence: case false, concocted by police, inmates and Assistant Secretary Tarun Kumar Sarkar.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the appellant was that the case against him was completely false and had been concocted by the police with the help of the inmates

facts.text: Prosecution examined 23 witnesses including Sudharani Roy (PW2) and Narmaya (PW5).

anchor.surface_text: At the trial, the prosecution examined 23 witnesses, in support of the case against the accused. The two victims of the alleged outrage by the appellant,

facts.text: Sudharani's age estimated by medical evidence between 13 and 14 years on May 19, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The medical estimate of her age was that she was between 13 and 14 years on the date of the X-ray examination, that is May 19, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The jury returned a unanimous verdict of guilty against the accused in respect of the charge of committing rape on Sudharani

under art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution, is directed against the order of a Division Bench of that Court, dated February 15, 1955, summarily dismissing an appeal from the judgment and order dated January 22, 1955, passed by the learned Second Additional Sessions Judge of Alipore, accepting the unanimous verdict of guilty returned by the jury holding the appellant guilty under s. 376 of the Indian Penal Code, for having committed rape on a young girl, named Sudharani Roy, said to be about 14-15 years of age.

issues.text: Whether the preliminary objection regarding the validity of the certificate granted by the High Court under Article 134(1)(c) is sound

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the State of West Bengal raised a preliminary objection that the certificate granted by the Bench of the Calcutta High Court presided over by the learned Chief Justice, was bad on the face of the judgment given by him while granting the certificate. We have, therefore, first to examine whether the preliminary objection is sound.

issues.text: Whether there are any grounds on which this Court would have granted special leave to appeal under Article 136 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: But the appeal having been placed before this Court, we have to satisfy ourselves whether there are any grounds on which this Court would have granted special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution. In order to appreciate the grounds raised in support of the appeal by the learned counsel for the appellant, it is necessary to state the following facts

issues.text: Whether the learned judge rightly refused permission to counsel for the appellant to read out the written statement filed on behalf of the appellant at the Sessions stage to the jury
Whether there was a serious misdirection in respect of corroboration of the testimony of the alleged victims of rape
Whether the direction as to the age of the girl Sudharani was not complete
Whether one Division Bench of the High Court has jurisdiction to sit in judgment on the decision of another Division Bench

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the learned Chief Justice and his brother judge, contrary to the legal position that one Bench of the High Court has no jurisdiction to sit in judgment on the decision of another Division Bench, have, in fact, done so.

arguments.claim: The certificate granted by the High Court under Article 134(1)(c) is bad and invalid on the face of the judgment granting it

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the State of West Bengal raised a preliminary objection that the certificate granted by the Bench of the Calcutta High Court presided over by the learned Chief Justice, was bad on the face of the judgment given by him while granting the certificate.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: should also appear to have been done and therefore the evidence ought to have received a full companysideration by the appellate Court, although the r

arguments.court_reasoning: Certificate must certify complexities of law or substantial question requiring authoritative pronouncement; not for mere arguable points or appearance of justice; cites Haripada Dey and other authorities

arguments.claim: One Division Bench of the High Court has no jurisdiction to sit in judgment on the decision of another Division Bench

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the learned Chief Justice and his brother judge, contrary to the legal position that one Bench of the High Court has no jurisdiction to sit in judgment on the decision of another Division Bench, have, in fact, done so.

arguments.claim: Granting certificate merely because there were arguable points, accused not fully satisfied/heard, or to make justice appear done is improper

anchor.surface_text: We are oppressed by the feeling that there were arguable points, although they might not bear examination and the accused has not had the satisfaction of feeling that he has been fully heard by the Court of appeal. I would therefore grant him the leave he asks for, not because we take any view in his favour of the evidence in the case, but because justice should also appear to have been done

arguments.qualifiers: although they might not bear examination

court_response_anchor.surface_text: should also appear to have been done and therefore the evidence ought to have received a full companysideration by the appellate Court, although the r

arguments.court_reasoning: Art 134(1)(c) requires certifying fit case with legal complexities, not arguable points or appearance of justice; summary dismissal sanctioned by CrPC

arguments.claim: The Sessions Judge erred in refusing permission to read out the written statement filed by appellant at Sessions stage to the jury
arguments.court_reasoning: No CrPC provision for written statement at Sessions (unlike s256 magistrate cases); s342 provides oral statement; jury trial excludes non-evidence to avoid irrelevant matter

arguments.claim: There was a serious misdirection in the charge regarding corroboration of the testimony of the rape victims
arguments.court_reasoning: Charge emphasized prudence rule but clarified not mandatory law; treated prosecutrix as accomplice (favorable to accused); jury can convict on uncorroborated testimony if satisfied; cites Rameshwar v State of Rajasthan

arguments.claim: The direction in the charge as to the age of Sudharani was not complete
arguments.court_reasoning: Fair and full direction considered all evidence (register, medical X-ray, ossification, oral); benefit of doubt instructed; ossification not sure guide; no birth certificate available

arguments.claim: Under Art 134(1)(c), High Court erred in granting certificate on mere arguable points without legal complexities

anchor.surface_text: This Court has repeatedly called the attention of the High Courts to the legal position that under Art. 134(1)(c) of the Constitution, it is not a case of granting leave but of certifying that the case is a fit one for appeal to this Court. Certifying is a strong word and, therefore, it has been repeatedly pointed out that a High Court is in error in granting a certificate on a mere question of fact, and that the High Court is not justified in passing on an appeal for determination by this Court when there are no complexities of law involved in the case, requiring an authoritative interpretation by this Court.

arguments.claim: Practice of summary dismissal of appeals against jury verdicts is sanctioned by statute and necessary

anchor.surface_text: Such observations are not conducive to the maintenance of a healthy atmosphere for the administration of justice in the highest Court in the State. Furthermore, the observation almost amounts to a condemnation of the practice of summary dismissal of appeals, especially against orders passed in a case tried by a jury where the appellant has to make out clear grounds of law. Such a practice prevails, so far as we know, in almost all the High Courts in India and has the sanction of the statute law as contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure.

arguments.claim: There is no merit in the appeal on merits; no grounds for special leave under Art 136

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no merit in the appeal.

holdings.text: the certificate granted by the High Court is not a proper one. The preliminary objection is, therefore, upheld.

anchor.surface_text: In view of those authorities of this Court, it is clear that the certificate granted by the High Court is not a proper one. The preliminary objection is, therefore, upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 134(1)(c) requires certifying a fit case involving substantial questions of law of general importance or complexities requiring authoritative pronouncement by SC; High Court erred by granting on mere arguable points, appearance of justice, or full hearing satisfaction; follows precedents like Haripada Dey v. State of West Bengal.

holdings.text: one Bench of the High Court has no jurisdiction to sit in judgment on the decision of another Division Bench

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the learned Chief Justice and his brother judge, contrary to the legal position that one Bench of the High Court has no jurisdiction to sit in judgment on the decision of another Division Bench, have, in fact, done so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal position that coordinate benches cannot review each other; High Court bench improperly reviewed summary dismissal by another bench.

holdings.text: the learned Sessions Judge rightly refused to allow the written statement put in by the appellant, to be read out before the jury.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No CrPC provision for filing written statement at Sessions stage (unlike s.256 for magistrates); s.342 provides oral statement; in jury trial, must exclude non-evidence to prevent irrelevant/inadmissible matter burdening judge.

holdings.text: the learned Sessions Judge was fully justified in telling the jury that there was no rule of law or practice that there must be corroboration in every case, before a conviction for rape.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge correctly stated rule of prudence (not law) requiring corroboration of prosecutrix (not accomplice); jury may convict on uncorroborated testimony if satisfied; error in treating prosecutrix as accomplice favorable to accused; follows Rameshwar v. State of Rajasthan.

holdings.text: we do not find anything basically wrong with the direction in the charge to the jury as regards the age of the girl Sudharani
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direction fair, considered all evidence (register, X-ray, ossification, oral); instructed benefit of doubt; ossification not sure guide; no birth certificate; jury to weigh all circumstances.

holdings.text: there is no merit in the appeal.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No grounds warranting special leave under Art.136; no substance in contentions on written statement, corroboration, or age direction; charge fair and full; evidence sufficient for jury verdict.

holdings.text: the practice of summary dismissal of appeals, especially against orders passed in a case tried by a jury where the appellant has to make out clear grounds of law... has the sanction of the statute law as contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: Such a practice prevails, so far as we know, in almost all the High Courts in India and has the sanction of the statute law as contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Summary dismissal sanctioned by CrPC; necessary for jury appeals requiring clear legal errors; HC observations criticizing it improper.

precedents.citation: Haripada Dey v. The State of West Bengal  1

anchor.surface_text: Haripada Dey v. The State of West Bengal  1

precedents.case_name: Haripada Dey v. The State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: A High Court certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) cannot be granted on mere questions of fact or without complexities of law requiring authoritative interpretation by the Supreme Court

precedents.citation: Rameshwar v. The State of Rajasthan  1

anchor.surface_text: Rameshwar v. The State of Rajasthan  1

precedents.case_name: Rameshwar v. The State of Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: There is no rule of law or practice requiring corroboration of the prosecutrix's testimony in every rape case; it is a rule of prudence that must be present to the mind but corroboration is not compulsory
precedents.cited_holding: The only rule of law is that this rule of prudence must be present to the mind of the judge or the jury as the case may be and be understood and appreciated by him or them. There is no rule of practice that there must, in every case, be corroboration before a conviction can be allowed to stand.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal found to have no merit; conviction and sentence upheld
